## Description {#details}

Class to represent struct types.

There are two different kinds of struct types: Literal structs and Identified structs.

Literal struct types (e.g. &#123; i32, i32 &#125;) are uniqued structurally, and must always have a body when created. You can get one of these by using one of the <a href="#a18fc4545474c6ebb6f7c547f64f4fb31">StructType::get()</a> forms.

Identified structs (e.g. foo or %42) may optionally have a name and are not uniqued. The names for identified structs are managed at the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/llvmcontext">LLVMContext</a> level, so there can only be a single identified struct with a given name in a particular <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/llvmcontext">LLVMContext</a>. Identified structs may also optionally be opaque (have no body specified). You get one of these by using one of the <a href="#a82648246c07eb8a33f628eea28cb988c">StructType::create()</a> forms.

Independent of what kind of struct you have, the body of a struct type are laid out in memory consecutively with the elements directly one after the other (if the struct is packed) or (if not packed) with padding between the elements as defined by <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/datalayout">DataLayout</a> (which is required to match what the code generator for a target expects).

Definition at line 218 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/derivedtypes-h">DerivedTypes.h</a>.

### containsHomogeneousScalableVectorTypes() {#a3f0523418cc1edc3db74e7aadf8c1e67}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool StructType::containsHomogeneousScalableVectorTypes () const">
Returns true if this struct contains homogeneous scalable vector types.

Note that the definition of homogeneous scalable vector type is not recursive here. That means the following structure will return false when calling this function. &#123;&#123;&lt;vscale x 2 x i32&gt;, &lt;vscale x 4 x i64&gt;&#125;, &#123;&lt;vscale x 2 x i32&gt;, &lt;vscale x 4 x i64&gt;&#125;&#125;

## Private Member Attributes

### SymbolTableEntry {#aeece89c7043c0b3cb0d1187392f330b7}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void&#42; llvm::StructType::SymbolTableEntry = nullptr</>}>
For a named struct that actually has a name, this is a pointer to the symbol table entry (maintained by <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/llvmcontext">LLVMContext</a>) for the struct.

This is null if the type is an literal struct or if it is a identified type that has an empty name.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/derivedtypes-h/#l00239">239</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/derivedtypes-h">DerivedTypes.h</a>.

### get() {#af335143f4a0fb6ac98d6102219f9795a}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;class... Tys&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>static std::enable&#95;if&#95;t&lt; are&#95;base&#95;of&lt; Type, Tys... &gt;::value, StructType &#42; &gt; llvm::StructType::get (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; elt1, Tys &#42;... elts)</>}
  labels = {["inline", "static"]}>
This static method is a convenience method for creating structure types by specifying the elements as arguments.

Note that this method always returns a non-packed struct, and requires at least one element type.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/derivedtypes-h/#l00274">274</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/derivedtypes-h">DerivedTypes.h</a>.
